sp.p: You do, do you!—then let me ſee—what—if you go on a mile further, to the Buck's Head; the old Buck's Head on the hill, one of the beſt inns in the whole county?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: O ho! ſo we have eſcaped an adventure for This night, however.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: (Apart to Tony) Sure, you ben't ſending them to your father's as an inn, be you?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Mum, you fool you. Let them find that out. (To them.) You have only to keep on ſtraight forward, till you come to a large old houſe by the road ſide. You'll ſee a pair of large horns over the door. That's the ſign. Drive up the yard, and call ſtoutly about you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Sir, we are obliged to you. The ſervants can't, miſs the way?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, no: but I tell you though, the landlord is rich, and going to leave off buſineſs; ſo he wants to be thought a gentleman, ſaving your preſence, he! he! he! He'll be for giving you his company, and ecod if you mind him, he'll perſuade you that his mother was an alderman, and his aunt a juſtice of peace.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: A troubleſome old blade to be ſure; but a keeps as good wines and beds as any in the whole country.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Well, if he ſupplies us with theſe, we ſhall want no further connection. We are to turn to the right, did you ſay?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, no; ſtraight forward. I'll juſt ſtep myſelf, and ſhew you a piece of the way. (To the landlord) Mum.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Ah, bleſs your heart, for a ſweet, pleaſant—damn'd miſchievous ſon of a whore.

div.head: ACT THE SECOND.
div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE, followed by three or four aukward ſervants.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: WELL, I hope you're perfect in the table exerciſe I have been teaching you theſe three days. You all know your poſts and your places, and can ſhew that you have been uſed to good company, without ever ſtirring from home.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: When company comes, you are not to pop out and ſtare, and then run in again, like frighted rabbits in a warren.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
You, Diggory, whom I have taken from the barn, are to make a ſhew at the ſide-table; and you, Roger, whom I have advanced from the plough, are to
place yourſelf behind my chair. But you're not to ſtand ſo, with your hands in your pockets. Take your hands from your pockets, Roger; and from your head, you blockhead you. See how Diggory carries his hands. They're a little too ſtiff, indeed, but that's no great matter.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Aye, mind how I hold them. I learned to hold my hands this way, when I was upon drill for the militia. And ſo being upon drill—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You muſt not be ſo talkative, Diggory. You muſt be all attention to the gueſts. You muſt hear us talk, and not think of talking; you muſt ſee us drink, and not think of drinking; you muſt ſee us eat, and not think of eating.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: By the laws, your worſhip, that's parfectly unpoſſible. Whenever Diggory ſees yeating going forward, ecod he's always wiſhing for a mouthful himſelf.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Blockhead! Is not a belly-full in the kitchen as good as a belly-full in the parlour? Stay your ſtomach with that reflection.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Ecod I thank your worship, I'll make a ſhift to ſtay my ſtomach with a ſlice of cold beef in the pantry.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Diggory, you are too talkative. Then if I happen to ſay a good thing, or tell a good ſtory at table, you muſt not all burſt out a-laughing as if you made part of the company.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Then ecod your worſhip muſt not tell the ſtory of ould grouſe in the gun room: I can't help laughing at that—he! he! he!—for the ſoul of me. We have laughed at that theſe twenty years—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! The ſtory is a good one. Well, honeſt Diggory, you may laugh at that—but ſtill remember to be attentive. Suppoſe one of the company ſhould call for a glaſs of wine, how will you behave? A glaſs of wine, Sir, if you pleaſe, (To Diggory)—Eh, why don't you move?

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Ecod, your worſhip, I never have courage till I ſee the eatables and drinkables brought upo' the table, and then I'm as bauld as a lion.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: What, will nobody move?

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT.
sp.p: I'm not to leave this place.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT.
sp.p: I'm ſure it's no place of mine.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVANT.
sp.p: Nor mine, for ſartain.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Wauns, and I'm ſure it canna be mine.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You numbſkulls! and ſo while, like your betters, you are quarrelling for places, the gueſts muſt be ſtarved. O you dunces! I find I muſt begin all over again.—But don't I hear a coach drive into the yard? To your poſts, you blockheads. I'll go in the mean time and give my old friend's ſon a hearty reception at the gate.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: By the elevens, my place is gone quite out of my head.

sp.speaker: ROGER.
sp.p: I know that my place is to be every where.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT.
sp.p: Where the devil is mine?

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT.
sp.p: MY pleace is to be no where at all; and ſo ize go about my buſineſs.

div.stage: [Exeunt ſervants, running about as if frighted, different ways.
Enter SERVANT with Candles, ſhewing in MARLOW and HASTINGS.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Welcome, gentlemen, very welcome! This way.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: After the diſappointments of the day, welcome Once more, Charles, to the comforts of a clean room and a good fire. Upon my word, a very welllooking houſe; antique but creditable.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The uſual fate of a large manſion. Having firſt ruined the maſter by good houſekeeping, it at laſt comes to levy contributions as an inn.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: As you ſay, we paſſengers are to be taxed to pay all theſe fineries. I have often ſeen a good ſideboard, or a marble chimney-piece, though not actually put in the bill, inflame a reckoning confoundedly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Travellers, George, muſt pay in all places. The only difference is, that in good inns, you pay dearly for luxuries; in bad inns, you are fleeced and ſtarved.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You have lived pretty much among them. In truth, I have been often ſurpriſed, that you who have ſeen ſo much of the world, with your natural good ſenſe, and your many opportunities, could never yet acquire a requite ſhare of aſſurance.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
The Engliſhman's malady. But tell me, George, where • ould I have learned that aſſurance you talk
of? My life has been chiefly ſpent in a college, or an inn, in ſecluſion from that lovely part of the creation that chiefly teach men confidence. I don't know that I was ever familiarly acquainted with a ſingle modeſt woman—except my mother—But among females of another claſs you know—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Aye, among them you are impudent enough of all conſcience.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: They are of us, you know.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But in the company of women of reputation I never ſaw ſuch an idiot, ſuch a trembler; you look for all the world as if you wanted an opportunity of ſtealing out of the room.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Why, man, that's becauſe I do want to ſteal out of the room. Faith, I have often formed a reſolution to break the ice, and rattle away at any rate. But I don't know how, a ſingle glance from a pair of fine eyes has totally overſet my reſolution. An impudent fellow may counterfeit modeſty, but I'll be hanged if a modeſt man can ever counterfeit impudence.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: If you could but ſay half the fine things to them that I have heard you laviſh upon the bar-maid of an inn, or even a college bed-maker—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Why, George, I can't ſay fine things to them; they freeze, they petrify me. They may talk of a comet, or a burning mountain, or ſome ſuch bagatelle. But to me, a Modeſt woman, dreſt out in all her finery, is the moſt tremendous object of the whole creation.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! At this rate, man, how can you ever expect to marry?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Never, unleſs, as among kings and princes, my bride were to be courted by proxy. If, indeed, like an eaſtern bridegroom, one were to be introduced to a wife he never ſaw before, it might be endured. But to go through all the terrors of a formal courtſhip, together with the epiſode of aunts, grandmothers, and couſins, and at laſt to blurt out the broad ſtaring queſtion of, madam, will you marry me? No, no, that's a ſtrain much above me, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I pity you. But how do you intend behaving to the lady you are come down to viſit at the requeſt of your father?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: As I behave to all other ladies. Bow very low. Anſwer yes, or no, to all her demands—But for the reſt, I don't think I ſhall venture to look in her face, till I ſee my father's again.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I'm ſurpriſed that one who is ſo warm a friend can be ſo cool a lover.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: To be explicit, my dear Haſtings, my chief inducement down was to be inſtrumental in forwarding your happineſs, not my own. Miſs Neville loves you, the family don't know you, as my friend you are ſure of a reception, and let honour do the reſt.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear Marlow! But I'll ſuppreſs the emotion. Were I a wretch, meanly ſeeking to carry off a fortune, you ſhould be the laſt man in the world I would apply to for aſſiſtance. But Miſs Neville's perſon is all I aſk, and that is mine, both from her deceaſed father's conſent, and her own inclination.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Happy man! You have talents and art to captivate any woman. I'm doom'd to adore the ſex, and yet to converſe with the only part of it I deſpiſe. This ſtammer in my addreſs, and this aukward prepoſſeſſing viſage of mine, can never permit me to ſoar above the reach of a milliner's 'prentice, or one of the ducheſſes of Drury-lane. Pſhaw! this fellow here to interrupt us.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Gentlemen, once more you are heartily welcome. Which is Mr. Marlow? Sir, you're heartily welcome. It's not my way, you ſee, to receive my friends with my back to the fire. I like to give them a hearty reception in the old ſtyle at my gate. I like to ſee their horſes and trunks taken care of.

sp.speaker: MARLOW (aſide.)
sp.p: He has got our names from the ſervants already. (To him) We approve your caution and hoſpitality, Sir. (To Haſtings) I have been thinking, George, of changing our travelling dreſſes in the morning. I am grown confoundedly aſhamed of mine.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I beg, Mr. Marlow, you'll uſe no ceremony in this houſe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I fancy, George, you're right: the firſt blow is half the battle. I intend opening the campaign with the white and gold.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Mr. Marlow—Mr. Haſtings—gentlemen—pray be under no conſtraint in this houſe. This is Liberty-hall, gentlemen. You may do juſt as you pleaſe here.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
Yet, George, if we open the campaign too fiercely at firſt, we may want ammunition before it
is over. I think to reſerve the embroidery to ſecure a retreat.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Your talking of a retreat, Mr. Marlow, puts me in wind of the duke of Marlborough, when we went to beſiege Denain. He firſt ſummoned the garriſon.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Don't you think the ventre dór waiſtcoat will do with the plain brown?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He firſt ſummoned the garriſon, which might conſiſt of about five thouſand men—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I think not: brown and yellow mix but very poorly.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſay, gentlemen, as I was telling you, he ſummoned The garriſon, which might conſiſt of about five thouſand men—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The girls like finery.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Which might conſiſt of about five thouſand men, well appointed with ſtores ammunition, and other implements of war. Now, ſays the duke of Marlborough to George Brooks, that ſtood next to him—you muſt have heard of George Brooks—I'll
pawn my dukedom, ſays he, but I take that garriſon without ſpilling a drop of blood. So—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What, my good friend, if you gave us a glaſs of punch in the mean time, it would help us to carry on the ſiege with vigour.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Punch, Sir! (Aſide) This is the moſt unaccountable kind of modeſty I ever met with.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, punch. A glaſs of warm punch, after our journey, will be comfortable. This is Liberty-hall, you know.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Here's cup, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) So this fellow, in his Liberty-hall, will only let us have juſt what he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Taking the cup) I hope you'll find it to your mind. I have prepared it with my own hands, and I believe you'll own the ingredients are tolerable. Will you be ſo good as to pledge me, Sir? Here, Mr. Marlow, here is to our better acquaintance. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) A very impudent fellow this! but he's a character and I'll humour him a little. Sir, my ſervice to you. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (Aſide) I ſee this fellow wants to give us his company, and forgets that he's an innkeeper, before he has learned to be a gentleman.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: From the excellence of your cup, my old friend, I ſuppoſe you have a good deal of buſineſs in this part of the country. Warm work, now and then, at elections, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have long given that work over. Since our betters have hit upon the expedient of electing each other, there is no buſineſs 'for us that ſell ale.'

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So, then you have no turn for politics I find.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt. There was a time, indeed, I fretted myſelf about the miſtakes of government, like other people; but finding myſelf every day grow more angry, and the government growing no better, I left it to mend itſelf. Since that, I no more trouble my head about Heyder Ally or Ally Cawn, than about Ally Croaker. Sir, my ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So that with eating above ſtairs, and drinking below, with receiving your friends within, and amuſing them without, you lead a good pleaſant buſtling life of it.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I do ſtir about a great deal, that's certain. Half the differences of the pariſh are adjuſted in this very parlour.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (After drinking) And you have an argument in your cup, old gentleman, better than any in Weſtminſter-hall.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, young gentleman, that, and a little philoſophy.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Well, this is the firſt time I ever heard of an innkeeper's philoſophy.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So then, like an experienced general, you attack them on every quarter. If you find their reaſon manageable, you attack it with your philoſophy; if you find they have no reaſon, you attack them with this. Here's your health, my philoſopher. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Good, very good, thank you; ha! ha! Your generalſhip puts me in mind of prince Eugene, when he fought the Turks at the battle of Belgrade. You ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Inſtead of the battle of Belgrade, I believe it's almoſt time to talk about ſupper. What has your philoſophy got in the houſe for ſupper?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: For ſupper, Sir! (Aſide) Was ever ſuch a requeſt to a man in his own houſe!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſupper, Sir; I begin to feel an appetite. I ſhall make dev'liſh work to-night in the larder, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Such a brazen dog ſure never my eyes beheld. (To him) Why really, Sir, as for ſupper I can't well tell. My Dorothy, and the cook-maid, ſettle theſe things between them. I leave theſe kind of things entirely to then.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yon do, do you?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Entirely. By-the-bye, I believe they are in actual conſultation upon what's for ſupper this moment in the kitchen.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Then I beg they'll admit me as one of their privy council. It's a way I have got. When I travel, I always chuſe to regulate my own ſupper. Let the cook be called. No offence I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O no, Sir, none in the leaſt; yet I don't know how: our Bridget, the cook-maid, is not very communicative upon theſe occaſions. Should we ſend for her, ſhe might ſcold us all out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Let's ſee your liſt of the larder then. I aſk it as a favour. I always match my appetite to my bill of fare.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (To Hardcaſtle, who looks at them with ſurpriſe) Sir, he's very right, and it's my way too.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sir, you have a right to command here. Here, Roger, bring us the bill of fare for to-night's ſupper. I believe it's drawn out. Your manner, Mr. Haſtings, puts me in mind of my uncle, colonel Wallop. It was a ſaying of his, that no man was ſure of his ſupper till he had eaten it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (Aſide) All upon the high ropes! His uncle a colonel! We ſhall ſoon hear of his mother being a juſtice of peace. But let's hear the bill of fare.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Peruſing) What's here? For the firſt courſe; for the ſecond courſe; for the deſert. The devil, Sir, do you think we have brought down the whole joiners company, or the corporation of Bedford, to eat up ſuch a ſupper? Two or three little things, clean and comfortable, will do.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But, let's hear it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Reading) For the firſt courſe at the top, a pig, and pruin ſauce.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Damn your pig, I ſay.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And damn your pruin ſauce, ſay I.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet, gentlemen, to men that are hungry, pig, with pruin ſauce, is very good eating.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: At the bottom, a calve's tongue and brains.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Let your brains be knock'd out, my good Sir; I don't like them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Or you may clap them on a plate by themſelves.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Their impudence confounds me. (To them) Gentlemen, you are my gueſts, make what alterations you pleaſe. Is there any thing elſe you wiſh to retrench or alter, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Item. A pork pye, a boiled rabbit and ſauſages, a Florentine, a ſhaking pudding, and a diſh of tiff—taff—taffety cream!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p:
Confound your made diſhes, I ſhall be as much at a loſs in this houſe as at a green and yellow dinner
at the French ambaſſador's table. I'm for plain eating.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm ſorry, gentlemen, that I have nothing you like, but if there be any thing you have a particular fancy to—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Why, really, Sir, your bill of fare is ſo exquiſite, that any one part of it is full as good as another. Send us what you pleaſe. So much for ſupper. And now to ſee that our beds are air'd, and properly taken care of.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I entreat you'll leave all that to me. You ſhall not ſtir a ſtep.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Leave that to you! I proteſt, Sir, you muſt excuſe me, I always look to theſe things myſelf.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I muſt inſiſt, Sir, you'll make yourſelf eaſy on that head.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You ſee I'm reſolved on it. (Aſide.) A very troubleſome fellow this, as ever I met with.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'm reſolved at leaſt to attend you. (Aſide) This may be modern modeſty, but I never ſaw any thing look ſo like old-faſhioned impudence.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS, ſolus.
sp.p: So I find this fellow's civilities begin to grow troubleſome. But who can be angry at thoſe aſſiduities Which are meant to pleaſe him? Ha! what do I ſee? Miſs Neville, by all that's happy!

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: My dear Haſtings! To what unexpected good fortune? to what accident, am I to aſcribe this happy meeting?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Rather let me aſk the ſame queſtion, as I could never have hoped to meet my deareſt Conſtance at an inn.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: An inn! ſure you miſtake! my aunt, my guardian, lives here. What could induce you to think this hóuſe an inn?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My friend, Mr. Marlow, with whom I came down, and I, have been ſent here as to an inn, I aſſure you. A young fellow whom we accidentally met at a houſe hard by directed us hither.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Certainly it muſt be one of my hopeful couſin's tricks, of whom you have heard me talk ſo often, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: He whom your aunt intends for you? he of whom I have ſuch juſt apprehenſions?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: You have nothing to fear from him, I aſſure you. You'd adore him if you knew how heartily he deſpiſes me. My aunt knows it too, and has undertaken to court me for him, and actually begins to think ſhe has made a conqueſt.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Thou dear diſſembler! You muſt know, my Conſtance, I have juſt ſeized this happy opportunity of my friend's viſit here to get admittance into the family. The horſes that carried us down are now fatigued with their journey, but they'll ſoon be refreſhed; and then, if my deareſt girl will truſt in her faithful Haſtings, we ſhall ſoon be landed, in France, where even among ſlaves the laws of marriage are reſpected.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I have Often told you, that, though ready to obey you, I yet ſhould leave my little fortune behind with reluctance. The greateſt part of it was left me by my uncle, the India director, and chiefly conſiſts in jewels. I have been for ſome time perſuading my aunt to let me wear them. I fancy I'm very near ſucceeding. The inſtant they are put into my poſſeſſion you ſhall find me ready to make them and myſelf yours.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Periſh the baubles! Your perſon is all I deſire. In the mean time, my friend Marlow muſt not be let into his miſtake. I know the ſtrange reſerve of his temper is ſuch, that if abruptly informed of it, he would inſtanly quit die houſe before our plan was ripe for execution.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But how ſhall we keep him in the deception? Miſs Hardcaſtle is juſt returned from walking; what if we ſtill continue to deceive him?—This, this way—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The aſſiduities of theſe good people teize me beyond bearing. My hoſt ſeems to think it ill manners to leave me alone, and ſo he claps not only himſelf but his old-faſhioned wife on my back. They talk of coming to ſup with us too; and then, I ſuppoſe, we are to run the gauntlet through all the reſt of the family.—What have we got here!—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear Charles! Let me congratulate you!—The moſt fortunate accident!—Who do you think is juſt alighted?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Cannot gueſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Our miſtreſſes, boy, Miſs Hardcaſtle and Miſs Neville. Give me leave to introduce Miſs Conſtance Neville to your acquaintance. Happening to dine in the neighbourhood, they called, on their return, to take freſh horſes here. Miſs Hardcaſtle has juſt ſtept into the next room, and will be back in an inſtant. Wasn't it lucky? eh!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) I have been mortified enough of all conſcience, and here comes ſomething to complete my embarraſſment.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well! but was'nt it the moſt fortunate thing in the world?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! yes. Very fortunate—a moſt joyful encounter—But our dreſſes, George, you know are in diſorder—What if we ſhould poſtpone the happineſs 'till to-morrow?—To-morrow at her own houſe—It will be every bit as convenient—and rather more reſpectful—To-morrow let it be. [Offering to go.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: By no means, Sir. Your ceremony will diſpleaſe her. The diſorder of your dreſs will ſhew the ardour of your impatience. Beſides, ſhe knows you are in the houſe, and will permit you to ſee her.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: O! the devil! how ſhall I ſupport it? hem! hem! Haſtings, you muſt not go. You are to aſſiſt me, you know. I ſhall be confoundedly ridiculous. Yet, hang it! I'll take courage. Hem!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Pſhaw, man! it's but the firſt plunge, and all's over. She's but a woman, you know.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And of all women, ſhe that I dread moſt to encounter!

div.stage: Enter Miſs HARDCASTLE, as returned from walking, a bonnet, &c.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS, introducing them.
sp.p: Miſs Hardcaſtle, Mr. Marlow. I'm proud of bringing two perſons of ſuch merit together, that only want to know, to eſteem each other.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Now, for meeting my modeſt gentleman with a demure face, and quite in his own manner. (After a pauſe, in which be appears very uneaſy and diſconcerted.) I'm glad of your ſafe arrival, Sir—I'm told you had ſome accidents by the way.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Only a few, madam. Yes, we had ſome. Yes, madam, a good many accidents, but ſhould be ſorry—madam—or rather glad of any accidents—that are ſo agreeably concluded. Hem!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (To him) You never ſpoke better in your whole life. Keep it up, and I'll inſure you the victory.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm afraid you flatter, Sir. You that have ſeen ſo much of the fineſt company can find little entertainment in an obſcure corner of the country.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Gathering courage) I have lived, indeed, in the world, madam; but I have kept very little company. I have been but an obſerver upon life, madam, while others were enjoying it.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But that, I am told, is the way to enjoy it at laſt.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (To him) Cicero never ſpoke better. Once more, and you are confirmed in aſſurance for ever.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (To him) Hem! ſtand by me then, and when I'm down, throw in a word or two to ſet me up again.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: An obſerver, like you, upon life, were, I fear, diſagreeably employed, ſince you muſt have had much more to cenſure than to approve.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Pardon me, madam. I was always willing to be amuſed. The folly of moſt people is rather an object of mirth than uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (To him) Bravo, bravo. Never ſpoke ſo well in your whole life. Well! Miſs Hardcaſtle, I ſee that you and Mr. Marlow are going to be very good company. I believe our being here will but embarraſs the interview.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Mr. Haſtings. We like your company of all things. (To him) Zounds! George, ſure you won't go? how can you leave us?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Our preſence will but ſpoil converſation. ſo we'll retire to the next room. (To him) Yon don't conſider, man, that we are to manage a little tête-à-tête of our own.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (After a pauſe I But you have not been wholly an obſerver, I preſume, Sir: the ladies I ſhould hope have employed ſome part of your addreſſes.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Relapſing into timidity) Pardon me, madam, I—I—I—as yet have ſtudied—only—to—deſerve them.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And that, ſome ſay, is the very worſt way to obtain them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo madam. But I love to converſe only with the more grave and ſenſible part Of the ſex.—But I'm afraid I grow tireſome.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Not at all, Sir; there is nothing I like ſo much as grave converſation myſelf; I could hear it for ever. Indeed I have often been ſurpriſed how a man of ſentiment could ever admire thoſe light airy pleaſures, where nothing reaches the heart.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: It's—a diſeaſe—of the mind, madam. In the variety of taſtes there muſt be ſome who wanting a reliſh—for—um—a—um.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I underſtand you, Sir. There muſt be ſome, who wanting a reliſh for refined pleaſures, pretend to deſpiſe what they are incapable of taſting.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: My meaning, madam, but infinitely better expreſſed. And I can't help obſerving—a—

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Who could ever ſuppoſe this fellow impudent upon ſuch occaſions. (To him) You were going to obſerve, Sir—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I was obſerving, madam—I proteſt, madam, I forget what I was going to obſerve.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) I vow and ſo do I. (To him) You were obſerving, Sir, that in this age of hypocriſy ſomething about hypocriſy, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. In this age of hypocriſy there are few who upon ſtrict inquiry do not—a—a—a—

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I underſtand you perfectly, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) Egad! and that's more than I do myſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You mean that in this hypocritical age there are few that do not condemn in public what they practiſe in private, and think they pay every debt to virtue when they praiſe it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: True, madam; thoſe who have moſt virtue in their mouths, have leaſt of it in their boſoms. But I'm ſure I tire you, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Sir; there's ſomething ſo agreeable and ſpirited in your manner, ſuch life and force—pray, Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. I was ſaying—that there are ſome occaſions—when a total want of courage, madam, deſtroys all the—and puts us—upon a—a—a—

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
I agree with you entirely, a want of courage upon ſome occaſions aſſumes the appearance of ignorance
and betrays us when we moſt want to excel. I beg you'll proceed.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. Morally ſpeaking, madam—But I ſee Miſs Neville expecting us in the next room. I would not intrude for the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir, I never was more agreeably entertained in all my life. Pray go on.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. I was—But ſhe beckons us to join her. Madam, ſhall I do myſelf the honour to attend you?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well then, I'll follow.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) This pretty ſmooth dialogue has done for me.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE, ſola.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Was there ever ſuch a ſober ſentimental interview? I'm certain he ſcarce look'd in my face the whole time. Yet the fellow, but for his unaccountable baſhfulneſs, is pretty well too. He has good ſenſe, but then ſo buried in his fears, that it fatigues one more than ignorance. If I could teach him a little confidence, it would be doing ſomebody that I know of a piece of ſervice. But who is that ſomebody?—That, faith, is a queſtion I can ſcarce anſwer.

div.stage: Enter TONY and Miſs NEVILLE, followed by Mrs. HARDCASTLE and HASTINGS.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What do you follow me for, couſin Con? I wonder you're not aſham'd to be ſo very engaging.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I hope, couſin, one may ſpeak to one's own relations, and not be to blame.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aye, but I know what ſort of a relation you want to make me though; but it won't do. I tell you, couſin Con, it won't do; ſo I beg you'll keep your diſtance, I want no nearer relationſhip.
She follows, coquetting him to the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well! I vow, Mr. Haſtings, you are very entertaining. There's nothing in the world I love to talk of ſo much as London, and the faſhions, though I was never there myſelf.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Never there! You amaze me! From your air and manner, I conclude you had been bred all your life either at Ranelagh, St. James's, or Tower Wharf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
O! Sir, you're only pleaſed to ſay ſo. We country perſons can have no manner at all. I'm in love with the town, and that ſerves to raiſe me
above ſome of our neighbouring ruſtics; but who can have a manner, that has never ſeen the Pantheon, the Grotto Gardens, the Borough, and ſuch places where the nobility chiefly reſort? All I can do, is to enjoy London at ſecond-hand. I take care to know every tête-à-tête from the ſcandalous magazine, and have all the faſhions, as they come out, in a letter from the two Miſs Rickets of Crookedlane. Pray how do you like this head, Mr. Haſtings?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Extremely elegant and degagée, upon my word, madam. your friſeur is a Frenchman, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I proteſt I dreſſed it myſelf from a print in the ladies memorandum-book for the laſt year.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Indeed! Such a head in a ſide-box, at the playhouſe, would draw as many gazers as my lady may'reſs at a city ball.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I vow, ſince inoculation began, there is no ſuch thing to be ſeen as a plain woman; ſo one muſt dreſs a little particular, or one may eſcape in the crowd.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But that can never be your caſe, madam, in any dreſs. (Bowing.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yet, what ſignifies my dreſſing when I have ſuch a piece of antiquity by my ſide as Mr. Hardcaſtle: all I can ſay will never argue down a ſingle button from his cloaths. I have often wanted him to throw off his great flaxen wig, and where he was bald, to plaiſter it over, like my Lord Pately, with powder.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You are right, madam; for, as among the ladies there are none ugly, ſo among the men there are none old.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But what do you think his anſwer was? Why, with his uſual Gothic vivacity, he ſaid I only wanted him to throw off his wig to convert it into a tête for my own wearing.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Intolerable! At your age you may wear what you pleaſe, and it muſt become you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Haſtings, what do you take to be the moſt faſhionable age about town?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Some time ago, forty was all the mode; but I'm told the ladies intend to bring up fifty for the enſuing winter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Seriouſly. Then I ſhall be too young for the faſhion.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: No lady begins now to put on jewels 'till ſhe's paſt forty. For inſtance, Miſs there, in a polite circle, would be conſidered as a child, as a mere maker of ſamplers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet Mrs. Niece thinks herſelf as much a woman, and is as fond of jewels as the oldeſt of us all.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Your niece, is ſhe? And that young gentleman, a brother of yours, I ſhould preſume?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My ſon, Sir. They are contracted to each other. Obſerve their little ſports. They fall in and out ten times a day, as if they were man and wife already. (To them) Well, Tony, child, what ſoft things are you ſaying to your couſin Conſtance this evening?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I have been ſaying no ſoft things; but that it's very hard to be followed about ſo. Ecod! I've not a place in the houſe now that's left to myſelf, but the ſtable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Never mind him, Con, my dear. He's in another ſtory behind your back.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: There's ſomething generous in my couſin's manner. He falls out before faces to be forgiven in private.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's a damned confounded—crack.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ah! he's a ſly one. Don't you think they're like each other about the month, Mr. Haſtings? The Blenkinſop mouth to a T. They're of a ſize too. Back to back, my pretties, that Mr. Haſtings may ſee you. Come, Tony.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: You had as good not make me, I tell you.
Meaſuring.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: O lud! he has almoſt cracked my head.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O the monſter! For ſhame, Tony. You a man, and behave ſo!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: If I'm a man, let me have my fortin. Ecod! I'll not be made a fool of no longer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Is this, ungrateful boy, all that I'm to get for the pains I have taken in your education? I that have rock'd yon in your cradle, and fed that pretty mouth with a ſpoon! Did not I work that waiſtcoat to make you genteel? Did not I preſcribe for
you every day, and weep while the receipt was operating?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod! you had reaſon to weep, for you have been doſing me ever ſince I was born. I have gone through every receipt in the complete houſewife ten times over; and you have thoughts of courſing me through Quincy next ſpring. But, ecod! I tell you, I'll not be made a fool of no longer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Wasn't it all for your good, viper? Wasn't it all for your good?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I wiſh you'd let me and my good alone then. Snubbing this way when I'm in ſpirits. If I'm to have any good, let it come of itſelf; not to keep dinging it, dinging it into one ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: That's falſe; I never ſee you when you're in ſpirits. No, Tony, you then go to the alehouſe or kennel. I'm never to be delighted with your agreeable, wild notes, unfeeling monſter!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod! mamma, your own notes are the wildeſt of the two.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Was ever the like? But I ſee he wants to break my heart, I ſee he does.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Dear madam, permit me to lecture the young gentleman a little. I'm certain I can perſuade him to his duty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well! I muſt retire. Come, Conſtance, my love. You ſee, Mr. Haſtings, the wretchedneſs of my ſituation: was ever poor woman ſo plagued with a dear, ſweet, pretty, provoking, undutiful boy.

sp.speaker: TONY, ſinging.
sp.p: "There was a young man riding by, and fain would have his will. Rang do didlo dee."—Don't mind her. Let her cry. It's the comfort of her heart. I have ſeen her and ſiſter cry over a book for an hour together, and they ſaid, they liked the book the better the more it made them cry.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then you're no friend to the ladies, I find, my pretty young gentleman?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's as I find 'um.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Not to her of your mother's chuſing, I dare anſwer? And yet ſhe appears to me a pretty well-tempered girl.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's becauſe you don't know her as well as I. Ecod! I know every inch about her; and there's not a more bitter cantanckerous toad in all chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (Aſide) Pretty encouragement this for a lover!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I have ſeen her ſince the height of that. She has as many tricks as a hare in a thicket, or a colt the firſt day's breaking.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: To me ſhe appears ſenſible and ſilent!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aye, before company. But when ſhe's with her play-mate ſhe's as loud as a hog in a gate.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But there is a meek modeſty about her that charms me.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Yes, but curb her never ſo little, ſhe kicks up, and you're flung in a ditch.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well, but you muſt allow her a little beauty.—Yes, you muſt allow her ſome beauty.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p:
Bandbox! She's all a made up thing, mum. Ah! could you but ſee Bet Bouncer of theſe parts,
you might then talk of beauty. Ecod, ſhe has two eyes as black as ſtoes, and cheeks as broad and red as a pulpit cuſhion. She'd make two of ſhe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you to a friend that would take this bitter bargain off your hands?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Would you thank him that would take Miſs Neville, and leave you to happineſs and your dear Betſy?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aye; but where is there ſuch a friend, for who would take her?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I am he. If you but aſſiſt me, I'll engage to whip her off to France, and you ſhall never hear more of her.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aſſiſt you! Ecod I will, to the laſt drop of my blood. I'll clap a pair of horſes to your chaiſe that ſhall trundle you off in a twinkling, and may be get you a part of her fortin beſide, in jewels, that you little dream of.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear 'ſquire, this looks like a lad of ſpirit.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Come along then, and you ſhall ſee more of my ſpirit before you have done with me.
Singing.
We are the boys
That fears no noiſe
Where the thundering cannons roar.

div.head: ACT THE THIRD.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: WHAT could my old friend Sir Charles mean by recommending his ſon as the modeſteſt young man in town? To me he appears the moſt impudent piece of braſs that ever ſpoke with a tongue. He has taken poſſeſſion of the eaſy chair by the fireſide already. He took off his boots in the parlour, and deſired me to ſee them taken care of. I'm deſirous to know how his impudence affects my daughter.—She will certainly be ſhocked at it.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, my Kate, I ſee you have changed your dreſs as I bid you; and yet, I believe, there was no great occaſion.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I find ſuch a pleaſure, Sir, in obeying your commands, that I take care to obſerve them without ever debating their propriety.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet, Kate, I ſometimes give you ſome cauſe, particularly when I recommended my modeſt gentleman to you as a lover to-day.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You taught me to expect ſomething extraordinary, and I find the original exceeds the deſcription.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I was never ſo ſurpriſed in my life! He has quite confounded all my faculties!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I never ſaw any thing like it: and a man of the world too!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, he learned it all abroad,—what a fool was I, to think a young man could learn modeſty by travelling. He might as ſoon learn wit at a maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: It ſeems all natural to him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A good deal aſſiſted by bad company and a French dancing-maſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sure you miſtake, papa! A French dancingmaſter could never have taught him that timid look,—that aukward addreſs,—that baſhful manner—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Whoſe look? whoſe manner, child?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Mr. Marlow's: his mauvaiſe honte, his timidity ſtruck me at the firſt ſight.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then your firſt ſight deceived you; for I think him one of the moſt brazen firſt ſights that ever aſtoniſhed my ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, you rally! I never ſaw any one ſo modeſt.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And can you be ſerious! I never ſaw ſuch a bouncing ſwaggering puppy ſince I was born. Bully Dawſon was but a fool to him.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Surpriſing! He met me with a reſpectful bow, a ſtammering voice, and a look fixed on the ground.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He met me with a loud voice, a lordly air, and a familiarity that made my blood freeze again.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He treated me with diffidence and reſpect; cenſured the manners of the age; admired the prudence of girls that never laughed; tired me with apologies for being tireſome; then left the room with a bow, and, "madam, I would not for the world detain you."

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
He ſpoke to me as if he knew me all his life before. Aſked twenty queſtions, and never, waited
for an anſwer, interrupted my beſt remarks with ſome, ſilly pun, and when I was in my beſt ſtory of the Duke of Marlborough and Prince Eugene, he aſked if I had not a good hand at making punch. Yes, Kate, he aſked your father if he was a maker of punch.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: One of us muſt certainly be miſtaken.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: If he be what he he has ſhewn himſelf, I'm determined he ſhall never have my conſent.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And if he be the fullen thing I take him, he ſhall never have mine.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: In one thing then we are agreed—to reject him.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes. But upon conditions. For if you ſhould find him leſs impudent, and I more preſuming; if you find him more reſpectful, and I more importunate—I don't know—the fellow is well enough for a man—Certainly we don't meet many ſuch at a horſe race in the country.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: If we ſhould find him ſo—But that's impoſſible. The firſt appearance has done my buſineſs. I'm ſeldom deceived in that.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet there may be many good qualities under that firſt appearance.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, when a girl finds a fellow's outſide to her taſte, ſhe then ſets about gueſſing the reſt of his furniture. With her, a ſmooth face ſtands for good ſenſe, and a genteel figure for every virtue.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, a converſation begun with a compliment to my good ſenſe won't end with a ſneer at my underſtanding?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pardon me, Kate. But if young Mr. Brazen can find the art of reconciling contradictions, he may pleaſe us both, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And as one of us muſt be miſtaken, what if we go to make further diſcoveries?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Agreed. But depend on't I'm in the right.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And depend on't I'm not much in the wrong.

div.stage: Enter TONY, running in with a caſket.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod! I have got them. Here they are. My couſin Con's necklaces, bobs and all. My mother ſhan't cheat the poor ſouls out of their fortin neither. O! my genus, is that you?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear friend, how have you managed with your mother? I hope you have amuſed her with pretending love for your couſin, and that you are willing to be reconciled at laſt? Our horſes will be refreſhed in a ſhort time, and we ſhall ſoon be ready to ſet off.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: And here's ſomething to bear your charges by the way, (giving the caſket) your ſweetheart's jewels. Keep them, and hang thoſe, I ſay, that would rob you of one of them.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But how have you procured them from your mother?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aſk me no queſtions, and I'll tell you no fibs. I procured them by the rule of thumb. If I had not a key to every drawer in mother's bureau, how could I go to the alehouſe ſo often as I do? An honeſt man may rob himſelf of his own at any time.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Thouſands do it every day. But to be plain with you, Miſs Neville is endeavouring to procure them from her aunt this very inſtant. If ſhe ſucceeds, it will be the moſt delicate way at leaſt of obtaining them.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Well, keep them, till you know how it will be. But I know how it will be well enough, ſhe'd as ſoon part with the only ſound, tooth in her head.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But I dread the effects of her reſentment, when ſhe finds ſhe has loſt them.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Never you mind her reſentment, leave me to manage that. I don't value her reſentment the bounce of a cracker. Zounds! here they are. Morrice! Prance!

div.stage: TONY, Mrs. HARDCASTLE, and Miſs NEVILLE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Indeed, Conſtance, you amaze me. Such a girl as you want jewels? It will be time enough for jewels, my dear, twenty years hence, when your beauty begins to want repairs.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But what will repair beauty at forty, will certainly improve it at twenty, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Yours, my dear, can admit of none. That natural bluſh is beyond a thouſand ornaments. Beſides, child, jewels are quite out at preſent. Don't you ſee half the ladies of our acquaintance, my lady Kill-day-light, and Mrs. Crump, and the reſt of
them, carry their jewels to town, and bring nothing but paſte and marcaſites back.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But who knows, madam, but ſomebody that ſhall be nameleſs would like me beſt with all my little finery about me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Conſult your glaſs, my dear, and then ſee if, with ſuch a pair of eyes, you want any better ſparklers. What do you think, Tony, my dear? does your couſin Con, want any jewels, in your eyes, to ſet off her beauty?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's as thereafter may be.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: My dear aunt, if you knew how it would oblige me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A parcel of old-faſhioned roſe and table cut things. They would make you look like the court of king Solomon at a puppet-ſhew. Beſides, I believe I can't readily come at them. They may be miſſing for aught I know to the contrary.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (Apart to Mrs. Hardcaſtle.) Then why don't you tell her ſo at once, as ſhe's ſo longing for them? Tell her they're loſt. It's the only way to quiet her. Say they're loſt, and call me to bear witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Apart to Tony.) You know, my dear, I'm only keeping them for you. So if I ſay they're gone, you'll bear me witneſs, will you? He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.p: Never ſear me. Ecod! I'll ſay I ſaw them taken out with my own eyes.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I deſire them but for a day, madam. Juſt to be permitted to ſhew them as relics, and then they may be lock'd up again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: To be plain with you, my dear Conſtance; if I could find them, you ſhould have them. They're miſſing, I aſſure you. Loſt, for aught I know; but we muſt have patience wherever they are.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I'll not believe it; this is but a ſhallow pretence to deny me. I know they're too valuable to be ſo ſlightly kept, and as you are to anſwer for the loſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Don't be alarm'd, Conſtance. If they be loſt, I muſt reſtore an equivalent. But my ſon knows they are miſſing, and not to be found.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That I can bear witneſs to. They are miſſing, and not to be found, I'll take my oath on't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You muſt learn reſignation, my dear; for though we loſe our fortune, yet we ſhould not loſe our patience. See me, how calm I am.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Aye, people are generally calm at the misfortunes of others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Now, I wonder a girl of your good ſenſe ſhould waſte a thought upon ſuch trumpery. We ſhall ſoon find them; and, in the mean time, you ſhall make uſe of my garnets till your jewels be found.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I deteſt garnets.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The moſt becoming things in the world to ſet off a clear complexion. You have often ſeen how well they look upon me, You shall have them.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I diſlike them of all things. You ſhan't ſtir.—Was ever any thing ſo provoking to miſlay my own jewels, and force me to wear her trumpery.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Don't be a fool. If ſhe gives you the garnets, take what you can get. The jewels are your own already. I have ſtolen them out of her bureau, and ſhe does not know it. Fly to your ſpark, he'll tell you more of the matter. Leave me to manage her.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: My dear couſin!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Vaniſh. She's here, and has miſſed them already. Zounds! how ſhe fidgets and ſpits about like a catharine wheel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Confuſion! thieves! robbers! we are cheated, plundered, broke open, undone.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What's the matter, what's the matter, mamma? I hope nothing has happened to any of the good family!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: We are robbed. My bureau has been broke open, the jewels taken out, and I'm undone.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Oh! is that all? Ha! ha! ha! By the laws, I never ſaw it better acted in my life. Ecod, I thought you was ruin'd in earneſt, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Why, boy, I'm ruin'd in earneſt. My bureau has been broke open, and all taken away.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Stick to that; ha! ha! ha! ſtick to that. I'll bear witneſs, you know, call me to bear witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, Tony, by all that's precious, the jewels are gone, and I ſhall be ruin'd for ever.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Sure I know they're gone, and I'm to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My deareſt Tony, but hear me. They're gone, I ſay.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: By the laws, mamma, you make me for to laugh, ha! ha! I know who took them, well enough, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a blockhead, that can't tell the difference between jeſt and earneſt! I tell you I'm not in jeſt, booby.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's right, that's right: you muſt be in a bitter paſſion, and then nobody will ſuſpect either of us. I'll bear witneſs that they are gone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a croſs-grain'd brute, that won't hear me? Can you bear witneſs that you're no better than a fool? Was ever poor woman ſo beſet with fools on one hand, and thieves on the other.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I can bear witneſs to that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Bear witneſs again, you blockhead you, and I'll turn you out of the room directly. My poor niece, what will become of her! Do you laugh, you unfeeling brute, as if you enjoyed my diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I can bear witneſs to that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Do you inſult me, monſter? I'll teach you to vex your mother, I will.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I can bear witneſs to that.
He runs off, ſhe follows him.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: What an unaccountable creature is that brother of mine, to ſend them to the houſe as an inn, ha! ha! I don't wonder at his impudence.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: But what is more, madam, the young gentleman, as you paſſed by in your preſent dreſs, aſk'd me if you were the bar-maid? He miſtook you for the bar-maid, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Did he? Then as I live, I'm reſolved to keep up the deluſion. Tell me, Pimple, how do you like my preſent dreſs. Don't you think I look ſomething like Cherry in the Beaux Stratagem?

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: It's the dreſs, madam, that every lady wears is the country, but when ſhe viſits, or receives company.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And are you ſure he does not remember my face or perſon?

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: Certain of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I vow, I thought ſo? for though we ſpoke for ſome time together, yet his fears were ſuch, that he never once looked up during the interview. Indeed, if he had, my bonnet would have kept him from ſeeing me.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: But what do you hope from keeping him in his miſtake?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: In the firſt place, I ſhall be ſeen, and that is no ſmall advantage to a girl who brings her face to market. Then I ſhall perhaps make an acquaintance, and that's no ſmall victory gained over one who never addreſſes any but the wildeſt of her ſex. But my chief aim is to take my gentleman off his guard, and, like an inviſible champion of romance, examine the giant's force before I offer to combat.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: But are you ſure you can act your part, and diſguiſe your voice, ſo that he may miſtake that, as he has already miſtaken your perſon?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Never fear me. I think I have got the true barcant.—Did your honour call?—Attend the Lion
there.—Pipes and tobacco for the Angel.—The Lamb has been outrageous this half hour.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: It will do, madam. But he's here.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What a bawling in every part of the houſe! I have ſcarce a moment's repoſe. If I go to the beſt room, there I find my hoſt and his ſtory. If I fly to the gallery, there we have my hoſteſs with her courteſy down to the ground. I have at laſt got a moment to myſelf, and now for recollection. [Walks and muſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Did you call, Sir? Did your honour call?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Muſing.) As for Miſs Hardcaſtle, ſhe's too grave and ſentimental for me.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Did your honour call?
She ſtill places herſelf before him, be turning away.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: No, child, (muſing.) Beſides, from the glimpſe I had of her, I think ſhe ſquints.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm ſure, Sir, I heard the bell ring.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: No, no. (muſing.) I have pleaſed my father, however, by coming down, and I'll to-morrow pleaſe myſelf by returning.
Taking out his tablets, and peruſing.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Perhaps the other gentleman called, Sir?

sp.speaker: MARIOW.
sp.p: I tell you, no.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſhould be glad to know, Sir. We have ſuch a parcel of ſervants.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: No, no, I tell you. (Looks full in her face). Yes, child, I think I did call. I wanted—I wanted—I vow, child, you are vaſtly handſome.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O la, Sir, you'll make one aſham'd.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Never ſaw a more ſprightly malicious eye. Yes, yes, my dear, I did call. Have you got any of your—a—what d'ye call it in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: No, Sir, we have been out of that theſe ten days.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: One may call in this houſe, I find, to very little purpoſe. Suppoſe I ſhould call for a taſte, juſt by way of trial, of the nectar of your lips; perhaps I might be diſappointed in that too.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Nectar! nectar! That's a liquor there's no call for in thoſe parts. French, I ſuppoſe. We keep no French wines here, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Of true Engliſh growth, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then it's odd I ſhould not know it. We brew all ſorts of wines in this houſe, and I have lived here theſe eighteen years.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Eighteen years! Why one would think, child, you kept the bar before you were born. How old are you?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O! Sir, I muſt not tell my age. They ſay women and muſic ſhould never be dated.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: To gueſs at this diſtance you can't be much above forty (approaching). Yet nearer I don't think ſo much (approaching). By coming cloſe to ſome women they look younger ſtill; but when we come very cloſe indeed— (attempting to kiſs her).

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, keep your diſtance. One would think you wanted to know one's age as they do horſes, by mark of mouth.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I proteſt, child, you uſe me extremely ill. If you keep me at this diſtance, how is it poſſible you and I can ever be acquainted?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And who wants to be acquainted with you? I want no ſuch acquaintance, not I. I'm ſure you did not treat Miſs Hardcaſtle that was here awhile ago in this obſtropalous manner. I'll warrant me, before her you look'd daſh'd, and kept bowing to the ground, and talk'd, for all the word, as if you was before a juſtice of peace.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) Egad! She has hit it, ſure enough. (To her) In awe of her, child ſ Ha! ha! ha! A mere, aukward, ſquinting thing, no, no. I find you don't know me. I laugh'd, and rallied her a little; but I was unwilling to be too ſevere. No, I could not be too ſevere, curſe me!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O! then, Sir, you are a favourite, I find, among the ladies?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
Yes, my dear, a great favourite. And yet, hang me, I don't ſee what they find in me to follow. At the ladies club in town, I'm called their agreeable Rattle. Rattle, child, is not my real name, but one I'm known by. My name is Solomons. Mr.
Solomons, my dear, at your ſervice. (Offering to ſalute her.)

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; you are introducing me to your club, not to yourſelf. And you're ſo great a favourite there, you ſay?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, my dear. There's Mrs. Mantrap, lady Betty Blackleg, the counteſs of Sligo, Mrs. Langhorns, old Miſs Biddy Buckſkin, and your humble ſervant, keep up the ſpirit of the place.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then it's a very merry place, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, as merry as cards, ſupper, wine, and old women, can make us.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And their agreeable Rattle, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) Egad! I don't quite like this chit. She looks knowing, methinks. You laugh, child!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I can't but laugh to think what time they all have for minding their work or their family.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) All's well; ſhe don't laugh at me. (To her) Do you ever work, child?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, ſure. There's not a ſcreen or a quilt in the whole houſe but what can bear witneſs to that.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Odſo! then you muſt ſhew me your embroidery. I embroider and draw patterns myſelf a little. If you want a judge of your work you muſt apply to me. [Seizing her hand.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, but the colours do not look well by candlelight. You ſhall ſee all in the morning.
Struggling.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And why not now, my angel? Such beauty fires beyond the power of reſiſtance—Pſhaw! the father here! My old luck: I never nick'd ſeven that I did not throw ames ace three times following.

div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE, who ſtands in ſurprize.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: So, madam. So I find this is your modeſt lover. This is your humble admirer that kept his eyes fixed on the ground, and only ador'd at humble diſtance. Kate, Kate, art thou not aſham'd to deceive your father ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Never truſt me, dear papa, but he's ſtill the modeſt man I firſt took him for, you'll be convinc'd of it as well as I.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: By the hand of my body I believe his impudence is infectious! Didn't I ſee him ſeize your hand? Didn't I ſee him hawl you about like a milk-maid? and now you talk of his reſpect and his modeſty, forſooth!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But if I ſhortly convince you of his modeſty, that he has only the faults that will paſs off with time, and the virtues that will improve with age, I hope you'll forgive him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The girl would actually make one run mad! I tell you I'll not be convinced. I am convinced. He has ſcarce been three hours in the houſe, and he has already encroached on all my prerogatives. You may like his impudence, and call it modeſty. But my ſon-in-law, madam, muſt have very different qualifications.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sir, I aſk but this night to convince you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You ſhall not have half the time, for I have thoughts of turning him out this very hour.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Give me that hour then, and I hope to ſatisfy you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, an hour let it be then. But I'll have no trifling with your father. All fair and open, do you mind me.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you have ever found that I conſidered your commands as my pride; for your kindneſs is ſuch, that my duty as yet has been inclination.

div.head: ACT THE FOURTH.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: YOU ſurpriſe me! Sir Charles Marlow expected here this night? Where have you had your information?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: You may depend upon it. I juſt ſaw his letter to Mr. Hardcaſtle, in which he tells him he intends ſetting out a few hours after his ſon.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then, my Conſtance, all muſt be compleated before he arrives. He knows me; and ſhould he find me here, would diſcover my name, and perhaps my deſigns, to the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: The jewels, I hope, are ſafe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p:
Yes, yes. I have ſent them to Marlow, who keeps the keys of our baggage. In the mean time, I'll go to prepare matters for our elopement. I have had the, ſquire's promiſe of a freſh pair of horſes;
and, if I ſhould not ſee him again, will write him further directions.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Well! ſucceſs attend you. In the mean time, I'll go amuſe my aunt with the old pretence of a violent paſſion for my couſin.

div.stage: Enter MARLOW, followed by a ſervant.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I wonder what Haſtings could mean by ſending me ſo valuable a thing as a caſket to keep for him, when he knows the only place I have is the ſeat of a poſtcoach at an inn-door. Have you depoſited the caſket with the landlady, as I ordered you? Have you put it into her own hands?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, your honour.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: She ſaid ſhe'd keep it ſafe, did ſhe?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe ſaid ſhe'd keep it ſafe enough; ſhe aſk'd me how I came by it? and ſhe ſaid ſhe had a great mind to make me give an account of myſelf.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! They're ſafe however. What an unaccountable ſet of beings have we got amongſt! This little bar-maid though runs in my head moſt ſtrangely, and drives out the abſurdities of all the
reſt of the family. She's mine, ſhe muſt be mine, or I'm greatly miſtaken.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Bleſs me! I quite forgot to tell her that I intended to prepare at the bottom of the garden. Marlow here, and in ſpirits too!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Give me joy, George! Crown me, ſhadow me with laurels! Well, George, after all, we modeſt fellows don't want for ſucceſs among the women.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Some women you mean. But what ſucceſs has your honour's modeſty been crowned with now, that it grows ſo inſolent upon us?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Didn't you ſee the tempting, briſk, lovely, little thing that runs about the houſe with a bunch of keys to its girdle?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: She's mine, you rogue you. Such fire, ſuch motion, ſuch eyes, ſuch lips—but, egad! ſhe would not let me kiſs them though.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But are you ſo ſure, ſo very ſure of her?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Why, man, ſhe talked of ſhewing me her work above ſtairs, and I am to improve the pattern.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But how can you, Charles, go about to rob a woman of her honour?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Pſhaw! pſhaw! We all know the honour of the bar-maid of an inn. I don't intend to rob her, take my word for it, there's nothing in this houſe, I ſhan't honeſtly pay for.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I believe the girl has virtue.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And if ſhe has, I ſhould be the laſt man in the world that would attempt to corrupt it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You have taken care, I hope, of the caſket I ſent you to lock up? It's in ſafety?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, yes. It's ſafe enough. I have taken care of it. But how could you think the ſeat of a poſtcoach at an inn-door a place of ſafety? Ah! Numbſkull! I have taken better precautions for you than you did for yourſelf.—I have—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I have ſent it to the landlady to keep for you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: To the landlady!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The landlady!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You did?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I did. She's to be anſwerable for its forth-coming, you know.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe'll bring it forth, with a witneſs.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Wasn't I right? I believe you'll allow that I acted prudently upon this occaſion?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (Aſide) He muſt not ſee my uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You ſeem a little diſconcerted though, methinks. Sure nothing has happened?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: No, nothing. Never was in better ſpirits in all my life. And ſo you left it with the landlady, who, no doubt, very readily undertook the charge?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Rather too readily. For ſhe nor only kept the caſket; but, through her great precaution, was going to keep the meſſenger too. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: He! he! he! They're ſafe however.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: As a guinea in a miſer's purſe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (Aſide) So now all hopes of fortune are at an end, and we muſt ſet off without it. (To him) Well, Charles, I'll leave you to your meditations on the pretty bar-maid, and, he! he! he! may you be as ſucceſsful for yourſelf as you have been for me.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Thank ye, George! I aſk no more. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I no longer know my own houſe. It's turned all topſey-turvey. His ſervants have got drunk already. I'll bear it no longer, and yet, from my reſpect for his father, I'll be calm. (To him) Mr. Marlow, your ſervant. I'm your very humble ſervant.
Bowing low.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, your humble ſervant. (Aſide) What's to be the wonder now?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, you muſt be ſenſible, Sir, that no man alive ought to be more welcome than your father's ſon, Sir. I hope you think ſo?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I do from my ſoul, Sir. I don't want much intreaty. I generally make my father's ſon welcome wherever he goes.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I believe you do, from my ſoul, Sir. But though I ſay nothing to your own conduct, that of your ſervants is unſufferable. Their manner of drinking is ſetting a very bad example in this houſe, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I proteſt, my very good Sir, that is no fault of mine. If they don't drink as they ought they are to blame. I ordered them not to ſpare the cellar. I did, I aſſure you. (To the ſide ſcene) Here, let one of my ſervants come up. (To him) My poſitive directions were, that as I did not drink myſelf, they ſhould make up for my deficiencies below.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then they had your orders for what they do! I'm ſatisfied!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: They had, I aſſure you. You ſhall hear from one of themſelves.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
You, Jeremy! Come forward, ſirrah! What were my orders? Were you not told to drink freely,
and call for what you thought fit, for the good of the houſe?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) I begin to loſe my patience.

sp.speaker: JEREMY.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour, liberty and Fleet-ſtreet for ever! Though I'm but a ſervant, I'm as good as another man. I'll drink for no man before ſupper, Sir, dammy! Good liquor will ſit upon a good ſupper, but a good ſupper will not ſit upon—hiccup—upon my conſcience, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You ſee, my old friend, the fellow is as drunk as he can poſſibly be. I don't know what you'd have more; unleſs you'd have the poor devil ſouſed in a beer-barrel.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Zounds! he'll drive me diſtracted if I contain myſelf any longer. Mr. Marlow. Sir; I have ſubmitted to your inſolence for more than four hours, and I ſee no likelihood of its coming to an end. I'm now reſolved to be maſter here, Sir, and I desire that you and your drunken pack may leave my houſe directly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Leave your houſe!—Sure you jeſt, my good friend? What, when I'm doing what I can to pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, you don't pleaſe me; ſo I deſire you'll leave my houſe.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sure you cannot be ſerious? at this time o'night, and ſuch a night. You only mean to banter me?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, I'm ſerious? and, now that my paſſions are rouzed, I ſay this houſe is mine, Sir; this houſe is mine, and I command you to leave it directly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! A puddle in a ſtorm. I ſhan't ſtir a ſtep, I aſſure you. (In a ſerious tone) This, your houſe, fellow! It's my houſe. This is my houſe. Mine, while I chuſe to ſtay. What right have you to bid me to leave this houſe, Sir? I never met with ſuch impudence, curſe me, never in my whole life before.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Nor I, confound me if ever I did. To come to my houſe, to call for what he likes, to turn me out of my own chair, to inſult the family, to order his ſervants to get drunk, and then to tell me "This houſe is mine, Sir." By all that's impudent it makes me laugh. Ha! ha! ha! Pray, Sir, (bantering) as you take the houſe, what think you of taking the reſt of the furniture? There's a pair of ſilver candleſticks, and there's a fire-ſcreen, and
here's a pair of brazen noſed bellows, perhaps you may take a fancy to them?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Bring me your bill, Sir; bring me your bill, and let's make no more words about it.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: There are a ſet of prints too. What think you of the rake's progreſs for your own apartment?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Bring me your bill, I ſay; and I'll leave you and your infernal houſe directly.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then there's a mahogany table that you may ſee your own face in.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: My bill, I ſay.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I had forgot the great chair, for your own particular ſlumbers, after a hearty meal.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Zounds! bring me my bill, I ſay, and let's hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Young man, young man, from your father's letter to me, I was taught to expect a well-bred modeſt man, as a viſitor here, but now I find him no better than a coxcomb and a bully; but he will be down here preſently, and ſhall hear more of it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: How's this! Sure I have not miſtaken the houſe! Every thing looks like an inn. The ſervants cry, coming. The attendance is aukward; the bar-maid too to attend us. But ſhe's here, and will further inform me. Whither ſo faſt, child? A word with you.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Let it be ſhort then. I'm in a hurry. (Aſide) I believe he begins to find out his miſtake, but it's too ſoon quite to undeceive him.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Pray, child, anſwer me one queſtion. What are you, and what may your buſineſs in this houſe be?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A relation of the family, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What, a poor relation?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. A poor relation appointed to keep the keys, and to ſee that the gueſts want nothing in my power to give them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: That is, you act as the bar-maid of this inn.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Inn. O law—What brought that in your head? One of the beſt families in the county keep an inn! Ha! ha! ha! old Mr. Hardcaſtle's houſe an inn!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Mr. Hardcaſtle's houſe! Is this houſe Mr. Hardcaſtle's houſe, child?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, ſure. Whoſe elſe ſhould it be?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: So then all's out, and I have been damnably impoſed on. O, confound my ſtupid head, I ſhall be laugh'd at over the whole town. I ſhall be ſtuck up in caricatura in all the print-ſhops. The Dulliſſimo Maccaroni. To miſtake this houſe of all others for an inn, and my father's old friend for an inn-keeper! What a ſwaggering puppy muſt he take me for? What a ſilly puppy do I find myſelf? There again, may I be hanged, my dear, but I miſtook you for the bar-maid.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Dear me! dear me! I'm ſure there's nothing in my behaviour to put me upon a level with one of that ſtamp.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
Nothing, my dear, nothing. But I was in for a liſt of blunders, and could not help making you a ſubſcriber. My ſtupidity ſaw every thing the wrong way. I miſtook your affiduity for aſſurance, and
your ſimplicity for allurement. But its over—This houſe I no more ſhew my face in.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I have done nothing to diſoblige you. I'm ſure I ſhould be ſorry to affront any gentleman who has been ſo polite, and ſaid ſo many civil things to me. I'm ſure I ſhould be ſorry (pretending to cry) if he left the family upon my account. I'm ſure I ſhould be ſorry, people ſaid any thing amiſs, ſince I have no fortune but my character.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) By Heaven, ſhe weeps. This is the firſt mark of tenderneſs I ever had from a modeſt woman, and it touches me. (To her) Excuſe me, my lovely girl, you are the only part of the family I leave with reluctance. But to be plain with you, the difference of our birth, fortune and education, make an honourable connection impoſſible: and I can never harbour a thought of ſeducing ſimplicity that truſted in my honour, of bringing ruin upon one, whoſe only fault was being too lovely.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Generous man! I now begin to admire him. (To him) But I'm ſure my family is as good as Miſs Hardcaſtle's, and though I'm poor, that's no great misfortune to a contented mind, and, until this moment, I never thought that it was bad to want fortune.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And why now, my pretty ſimplicity?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Becauſe it puts me at a diſtance from one, that if I had a thouſand pound I would give it all to.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Aſide) This ſimplicity bewitches me, ſo that if I ſtay I'm undone. I muſt make one bold effort, and leave her. (To her) Your partiality in my favour, my dear, touches me moſt ſenſibly, and were I to live for myſelf alone, I could eaſily fix my choice. But I owe too much to the opinion of the world, too much to the authority of a father, ſo that—I can ſcarcely ſpeak it—it affects me. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I never knew half his merit till now. He ſhall not go, if I have power or art to detain him. I'll ſtill preſerve the character in which I ſtoop'd to conquer, but will undeceive my papa, who, perhaps, may laugh him out of his reſolution.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aye, you may ſteal for yourſelves the next time. I have done my duty. She has got the jewels again, that's a ſure thing; but ſhe believes it was all a miſtake of the ſervants.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But, my dear couſin, ſure you won't forſake us in this diſtreſs. If ſhe in the leaſt ſuſpects that I am going off, I ſhall certainly be locked up, or ſent to my aunt Pedigree's, which is ten times worſe.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: To be ſure, aunts of all kinds are damn'd bad things. But what can I do? I have got you a pair of horſes that will fly like Whiſtlejacket, and I'm ſure you can't ſay but I have courted you nicely before her face. Here ſhe comes, we muſt court a bit Or two more, for fear ſhe ſhould ſuſpect us.
They retire, and ſeem to fondle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, I was greatly fluttered, to be ſure. But my ſon tells me it was all a miſtake of the ſervants. I ſhan't be eaſy, however, till they are fairly married, and then let her keep her own fortune. But what do I ſee! fondling together, as I'm alive. I never ſaw Tony ſo ſprightly before. Ah! have I caught you, my pretty doves! What, billing, exchanging ſtolen glances, and broken murmurs. Ah!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: As for murmurs, mother, we grumble a little now and then, to be ſure. But there's no love loſt between us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A mere ſprinkling, Tony, upon the flame, only to make it burn brighter.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Couſin Tony promiſes to give us more of his company at home. Indeed, he ſhan't leave us any more. It won't leave us, couſin Tony, will it?

sp.speaker: TONY.
