sp.p: O! it's a pretty creature. No, I'd ſooner leave my horſe in a pound, than leave you when you ſmile upon one ſo. Your laugh makes you ſo becoming.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Agreeable couſin! Who can help admiring that natural humour, that pleaſant, broad, red, thoughtleſs, (patting his cheek) ah! it's a bold face.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pretty innocence!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I'm ſure I always lov'd couſin Con's hazle eyes, and her pretty long fingers, that ſhe twiſts this way and that, over the haſpicholls, like a parcel of bobbins.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Ah, he would charm the bird from the tree. I was never ſo happy before. My boy takes after his father, poor Mr. Lumpkin, exactly. The jewels, my dear Con, ſhall be yours incontinently. You ſhall have them. Isn't he a ſweet boy, my dear?
You ſhall be married to-morrow, and we'll put off' the reſt of his education, like Dr. Drowſy's ſermons, to a fitter opportunity.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Where's the 'ſquire? I have got a letter for your worſhip.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Give it to my mamma. She reads all my letters firſt.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: I had orders to deliver it into your own hands.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Who does it come from?

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Your worſhip mun aſk that o' the letter itſelf.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I could wiſh to know, though (turning the letter, and gazing on it.)

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) Undone! undone! A letter to him from Haſtings. I know the hand. If my aunt ſees it we are ruined for ever. I'll keep her employ'd a little if I can. (To Mrs. Hardcaſtle) But I have not told yon, madam, of my couſin's ſmart anſwer juſt now to Mr. Marlow. We ſo laugh'd—You muſt know, madam,—This way a little, for he muſt not hear us.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (Still gazing) A damn'd cramp piece of penmanſhip, as ever I ſaw in my life. I can read your print hand very well. But here there are ſuch handles, and ſhanks, and daſhes, that one can ſcarce tell the head from the tail. "To Anthony Lumpkin, eſquire." It's very odd, I can read the outſide of my letters, where my own name is, well enough. But when I come to open it, it's all—buzz. That's hard, very hard; for the inſide of the letter is always the cream of the correſpondence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Very well, very well. And ſo my ſon was too hard for the philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Yes, madam; but you muſt hear the reſt, madam. A little more this way, or he may hear us. You'll hear how he puzzled him again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He ſeems ſtrangely puzzled now himſelf, methinks.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (Still gazing) A damn'd up and down hand, as if it was diſguiſed in liquor. (Reading) Dear Sir. Aye, that's that. Then there's an M, and a T, and an S, but whether the next be an izzard or an R, confound me, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: What's that, my dear. Can I give you any aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Pray, aunt, let me read it. No body reads a cramp hand better than I. (twitching the letter from her) Do you know who it is from?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Can't tell, except from Dick Ginger the feeder.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Aye, ſo it is, (pretending to read) Dear 'ſquire, hoping that you're in health, as I am at this preſent. The gentlemen of the Shake-bag club has cut the gentlemen of Gooſe-green quite out of feather. The odds—um—odd battle—um—long fighting—um—here, here, it's all about cocks and fighting; it's of no conſequence, here, put it up, put it up. [Thruſting the crumpled letter upon him.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: But I tell you, miſs, it's of all the conſequence in the world. I would not loſe the reſt of it for a guinea. Here, mother, do you make it out. Of no conſequence! [Giving Mrs. Hardcaſtle the letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
How's this! (reads) "Dear 'ſquire, I'm now waiting for Miſs Neville, with a poſt-chaiſe and pair, at the bottom of the garden, but I find my horſes yet unable to perform the journey. I expect you'll aſſiſt us with a pair of freſh horſes, as
you promiſed. Diſpatch is neceſſary, as the hag (aye the hag) your mother, will otherwiſe ſuſpect us. Yours, Haſtings." Grant me patience. I ſhall run diſtracted. My rage choaks me.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Curteſying very low.) Fine ſpoken, madam, you are moſt miraculouſly polite and engaging, and quite the very pink of curteſy and circumſpection, madam. (Changing her tone) And you, you great ill-faſhioned oaf, with ſcarce ſenſe enough to keep your mouth ſhut. Were you too join'd againſt me? But I'll defeat all your plots in a moment. As for you, madam, ſince you have got a pair of freſh horſes ready, it would be cruel to diſappoint them. So, if you pleaſe, inſtead of running away with your ſpark, prepare, this very moment, to run off with me. Your old aunt Pedigree will keep you ſecure, I'll warrant me. You too, Sir, may mount your horſe, and guard us upon the way. Here, Thomas, Roger, Diggory, I'll ſhew you, that I wiſh you better than you do yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: So now I'm completely ruined.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aye, that's a ſure thing.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: What better could be expected from being connected with ſuch a ſtupid fool, and after all the nods and ſigns I made him?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: By the laws, Miſs, it was your own cleverneſs, and not my ſtupidity, that did your buſineſs. You were ſo nice and ſo buſy with your Shake-bags and Gooſegreens, that I thought you could never be making believe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So, Sir, I find by my ſervant, that you have ſhewn my letter, and betray'd us. Was this well done, young gentleman?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Here's another. Aſk Miſs there who betray'd you? Ecod, it was her doing, not mine.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: So I have been finely uſed here among you. Rendered contemptible, driven into ill manners, deſpiſed, inſulted, laughed at.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Here's another. We ſhall have old Bedlam broke looſe preſently.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: And there, Sir, is the gentleman to whom we all owe every obligation.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What can I ſay to him, a mere boy, an idiot, whoſe ignorance and age are a protection.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: A poor contemptible booby, that would but diſgrace correction.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Yet with cunning and malice enough to make himſelf merry with all our embarraſſments.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: An inſenſible cub.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Replete with tricks and miſchief.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Baw! damme, but I'll fight you both one after the other,—with baſkets.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: As for him, he's below reſentment. But your conduct, Mr. Haſtings, requires an explanation. You knew of my miſtakes, yet would not undeceive me.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Tortured as I am with my own diſappointments, is this a time for explanations. It is not friendly, Mr. Marlow.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Mr. Marlow, we never kept on your miſtake, till it was too late to undeceive you. Be pacified.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: My miſtreſs deſires you'll get ready immediately, madam. The horſes are putting to. Your hat and things are in the next room. We are to go thirty miles before morning.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Well, well; I'll come preſently.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (To Haſtings) Was it well done, Sir, to aſſiſt in rendering me ridiculous. To hang me out for the ſcorn of all my acquaintance. Depend upon it, Sir, I ſhall expect an explanation.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Was it well done, Sir, if you're upon that ſubject, to deliver what I entruſted to yourſelf, to the care of another, Sir.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Mr. Haſtings. Mr. Marlow. Why will you increaſe my diſtreſs by this groundleſs diſpute? I implore, I intreat you—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Your cloak, madam. My miſtreſs is impatient.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I come. Pray be pacified. If I leave you thus, I ſhall die with apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Your fan, muff, and gloves, madam. The horſes are waiting.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: O, Mr. Marlow! if you knew what a ſcene of conſtraint and ill-nature lies before me, I'm ſure it would convert your reſentment into pity.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I'm ſo diſtracted with a variety of paſſions, that I don't know what I do. Forgive me, madam. George, forgive me. You know my haſty temper, and ſhould not exaſperate it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: The torture of my ſituation is my only excuſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Well, my dear Haſtings, if you have that eſteem for me that I think, that I am ſure you have, your conſtancy for three years will but encreaſe the happineſs of our future connexion. If—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Within) Miſs Neville. Conſtance, why Conſtance, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I'm coming. Well, conſtancy. Remember, conſtancy is the word.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My heart! how can I ſupport this. To be ſo near happineſs, and ſuch happineſs!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (To Tony) You ſee now, young gentleman, the effects of your folly. What might be amuſement to you, is here diſappointment, and even diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (From a reverie) Ecod, I have hit it. It's here. Your hands. Yours and yours, my poor Sulky. My boots there, ho. Meet me two hours hence at the bottom of the garden; and if you don't find Tony Lumpkin a more good-natur'd fellow than you thought for, I'll give you leave to take my beſt horſe, and Bet Bouncer into the bargain. Come along. My boots, ho!

div.head: ACT THE FIFTH.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: YOU ſaw the old lady and Miſs Neville drive off, you ſay.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, your honour. They went off in a poſt coach, and the young 'ſquire went on horſeback. They're thirty miles off by this time.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then all my hopes are over.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Old Sir Charles is arrived. He and the old gentleman of the houſe have been laughing at Mr. Marlow's miſtake this half hour. They are coming this way.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then I muſt not be ſeen. So now to my fruitleſs appointment at the bottom of the garden. This is about the time.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! The peremptory tone in which be ſent forth his ſublime commands.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: And the reſerve with which I ſuppoſe he treated all your advances.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet he might have ſeen ſomething in me above a common inn-keeper, too.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: Yes, Dick, but he miſtook you for an uncommon inn-keeper, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, I'm in too good ſpirits to think of any thing but joy. Yes, my dear friend, this union of our families will make our perſonal friendſhips hereditary; and though my daughter's fortune is but ſmall—

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: Why, Dick, will you talk of fortune to me? My ſon is poſſeſſed of more than a competence already, and can want nothing but a good and virtuous girl to ſhare his happineſs and encreaſe it. If they like each other, as you ſay they do—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: If, man! I tell you they do like each other. My daughter as good as told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: But girls are apt to flatter themſelves, you know.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſaw him graſp her hand in the warmeſt manner myſelf; and here he comes to put you out of your ifs, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I come, Sir, once more, to aſk pardon for my ſtrange conduct. I can ſcarce reflect on my inſolence without confuſion.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Tut, boy, a trifle. You take it too gravely. An hour or two's laughing with my daughter will ſet all to rights again. She'll never like you the worſe for it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall be always proud of her approbation.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
MARLOW.
sp.p: Really, Sir, I have not that happineſs.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Come, boy, I'm an old fellow, and know what's what, as well as you that are younger. I know what has paſt between you; but mum.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, nothing has paſt between us but the moſt profound reſpect on my ſide, and the moſt diſtant reſerve on hers. You don't think, Sir, that my impudence has been paſt upon all the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Impudence! No, I don't ſay that—not quite imprudence—though girls like to be play'd with, and rumpled a little too ſometimes. But ſhe has told no tales, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I never gave her the ſlighteſt cauſe.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, well, I like modeſty in its place well enough. But this is over-acting, young gentleman. You may be open. Your father and I will like you the better for it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: May I die, Sir, if I ever—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, ſhe don't diſlike you; and as I'm ſure you like her—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Dear, Sir—I proteſt,Sir—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſee no reaſon why you ſhould not be joined as faſt as the parſon can tie you.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: But hear me, Sir—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Your father approves the match, I admire it, every moment's delay will be doing miſchief, ſo—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: But why won't you hear me? By all that's juſt and true, I never gave Miſs Hardcaſtle the ſlighteſt mark of my attachment, or even the moſt diſtant hint to ſuſpect me of affection. We had but one interview, and that was formal, modeſt and unintereſting.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) This fellow's formal modeſt impudence is beyond bearing.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: And you never graſp'd her hand, or made any proteſtations.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: As Heaven is my witneſs, I came down in obedience to your commands. I ſaw the lady without emotion, and parted without reluctance. I hope you'll exact no further proofs of my duty, nor prevent me from leaving a houſe in which I ſuffer ſo many mortifications.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: I'm aſtoniſhed at the air of ſincerity with which he parted.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And I'm aſtoniſh'd at the deliberate intrepidity of his aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: I dare pledge my life and honour upon his truth.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Here comes my daughter, and I would ſtake my happineſs upon her veracity.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Kate, come hither, child. Anſwer us ſincerely, and without reſerve; has Mr. Marlow made you any profeſſions of love and affection?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The queſtion is very abrupt, Sir! But ſince you require unreſerved ſincerity, I think he has.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (To Sir Charles) You ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: And pray, madam, have you and my ſon had more than one interview?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſeveral.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (To Sir Charles) You ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: But did he profeſs any attachment?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A laſting one.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: Did he talk of love?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: Amazing! And all this formally?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Formally.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Now, my friend, I hope you are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: And how did he behave, madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: As moſt profeſt admirers do. Said ſome civil things of my face, talked much of his want of merit, and the greatneſs of mine; mentioned his heart, gave a ſhort tragedy ſpeech, and ended with pretended rapture.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p:
Now I'm perfectly convinced, indeed. I know his converſation among women to be modeſt and ſubmiſſive. This forward canting ranting manner
by no means deſcribes him, and, I am confident, he never ſate for the picture.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then what, Sir, if I ſhould convince you to your face of my ſincerity? If you and my papa, in about half an hour, will place yourſelves behind that ſcreen, you ſhall hear him declare his paſſion to me in perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: Agreed. And if I find him what you deſcribe, all my happineſs in him muſt have an end.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And if you don't find him what I deſcribe—I fear my happineſs muſt never have a beginning.

div.stage: SCENE changes to the Back of the Garden.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: What an idiot am I, to wait here for a fellow, who probably takes a delight in mortifying me. He never intended to be punctual, and I'll wait no longer. What do I ſee! It is he! and perhaps with news of my Conſtance.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My honeſt 'ſquire! I now find you a man of your word. This looks like friendſhip.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aye, I'm your friend, and the beſt friend you have in the world, if you knew but all. This riding by night, by the bye, is curſedly tireſome. It has ſhook me worſe than the baſket of a ſtagecoach.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But how? where did you leave your fellow travellers? Are they in ſafety? Are they houſed?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Five and twenty miles in two hours and a half is no ſuch bad driving. The poor beaſts have ſmoaked for it: rabbet me, but I'd rather ride forty miles after a fox, than ten with ſuch varment.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well, but where have you left the ladies? I die with impatience,

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Left them! Why where ſhould I leave them, but where I found them?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS,
sp.p: This is a riddle.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Riddle me this then. What's that goes round the houſe, and round the houſe, and never touches the houſe?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS,
sp.p: I'm ſtill aſtray.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Why that's it, mon. I have led them aſtray. By jingo, there's not a pond or ſlough within five miles of the place but they can tell the taſte of.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I underſtand; you took them in a round, while they ſuppoſed themſelves going forward, and ſo you have at laſt brought them home again.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: You ſhall hear: I firſt took them down Featherbed-lane, where we ſtuck faſt in the mud. I then rattled them crack over the ſtones of Up-and-down Hill—I then introduced them to the gibbet on Heavy-tree Heath, and from that with a circumbendibus, I fairly lodged them in the horſe-pond at the bottom of the garden.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But so accident, I hope.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, no. Only mother is confoundedly frightened. She thinks herſelf forty-miles off. She's ſick of the journey, and the cattle can ſcarce crawl. So if your own horſes be ready, you may whip off with coufin, and I'll be bound that no ſoul here can budge a foot to follow you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear friend, how can I be grateſul?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aye, now its dear friend, noble 'ſquire. Juſt now, it was all idiot, cub, and run me through the guts. Damn your way of fighting, I ſay. After we take a knock in this part of the country, we kiſs and be friends. But if you had run me through the guts, then I ſhould be dead, and you might go kiſs the hangman.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: The rebuke is juſt. But I muſt haſten to relieve Miſs Neville; if you keep the old lady employed, I promiſe to take care of the young one.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Never fear me. Here ſhe comes. Vaniſh. She's got from the pond, and draggled up to the waiſt like a mermaid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Oh, Tony, I'm killed. Shook. Battered to death. I ſhall never ſurvive it. That laſt jolt that laid us againſt the quickſet hedge has done my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Alack, mamma, it was all your own fault. You would be for running away by night, without knowing one inch of the way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I wiſh we were at home again. I never met ſo many accidents in ſo ſhort a journey. Drench'd in the mud, overturned in a ditch, ſtuck faſt in a ſlough, jolted to a jelly, and at laſt to loſe our way. Whereabouts do you think we are, Tony?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: By my gueſs we ſhould come upon Crackſkull common, about forty miles from home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O lud! O lud! The moſt notorious ſpot in all the country. We only want a robbery to make a complete night on't.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Don't be afraid, mamma, don't be afraid. Two of the five that kept here are hanged, and the other three may not find us. Don't be afraid. Is that a man that's galloping behind us? No; it's only a tree. Don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The fright will certainly kill me.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Do you ſee any thing like a black hat moving behind the thicket?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O death!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, it's only a cow. Don't be afraid, mamma; don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: As I'm alive, Tony, I ſee a man coming towards us. Ah! I'm ſure on't. If he perceives us we are undone.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: (Aſide) Father-in-law, by all that's unlucky, come to take one of his night walks. (To her) Ah, it's a highwayman, with piſtols as long as my arm. A damn'd ill-looking fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTIE.
sp.p: Good Heaven defend us! He approaches.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Do you hide yourſelf in that thicket, and leave me to manage him. If there be any danger I'll cough and cry hem. When I cough be ſure to keep cloſe.

div.stage: [Mrs. Hardcaſtle hides behind a tree in the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm miſtaken, or I heard voices of people in want of help. Oh, Tony, is that you? I did not expect you ſo ſoon back. Are your mother and her charge in ſafety?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Very ſafe, Sir, at my aunt Pedigree's. Hem.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (From behind) Ah death! I find there's danger.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Forty miles in three hours; ſure, that's too much, my youngſter.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Stout horſes and willing minds make ſhort journeys, as they ſay. Hem.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (From behind) Sure he'll do the dear boy no harm.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But I heard a voice here; I ſhould be glad to know from whence it came.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: It was I, Sir, talking to myſelf, Sir. I was ſaying that forty miles in four hours was very good going. Hem. As to be ſore it was. Hem. I have got a ſort of cold by being out in the air. We'll go in, if you pleaſe. Hem.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But if yon talk'd to yourſelf, you did not anſwer yourſelf. I am certain I heard two voices, and am reſolved (raiſing his voice) to find the other out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (From behind) Oh! he's coming to find me out. Oh!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What need yon go, Sir, if I tell you. Hem. I'll lay down my life for the truth—hem—I'll tell you all, Sir. [Detaining him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, I will not be detained. I inſiſt on ſeeing. It's in vain to expect I'll believe you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTIE.
sp.p: (Running forward from behind) O lud! he'll murder my poor boy, ray darling. Here good gentleman, whet your rage upon me. Take my money, my life, but ſpare that young gentleman, ſpare my child, if you have any mercy.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My wife! as I'm a Chriſtian. From whence can ſhe come? or what does ſhe mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Kneeling) Take compaſſion on us, good Mr. Highwayman. Take our money, our watches, all we have, but ſpare our lives. We will never bring you to juſtice, indeed we won't, good Mr. Highwayman.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I believe the woman's out of her ſenſes. What, Dorothy, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Mr. Hardcaſtle, as I'm alive! My fears blinded me. But who, my dear, could have expected to meet you here, in this frightful place, ſo far from home? What has brought you to follow us?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Sure, Dorothy, you have not loſt your wits? So far from home, when you are within forty yards of
your own door. (To him) This is one of your old tricks, you graceleſs rogue you. (To her) Don't you know the gate, and the mulberry-tree; and don't you remember the horſepond, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall remember the horſepond as long as I live; I have caught ray death in it. (To Tony) And is it to you, you graceleſs varlet, I owe all this. I'll teach you to abuſe your mother, I will.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod, mother, all the pariſh ſays you have ſpoil'd me, and ſo you may take the fruits on' t.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'll ſpoil you, I will.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: There's morality, however, in his reply.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear Conſtance, why will you deliberate thus? If we delay a moment, all is loſt for ever. Pluck up a little reſolution, and we ſhall ſoon be out of the reach of her malignity.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I find it impoſſible. My ſpirits are ſo ſunk with the agitations I have ſuffered, that I am unable to face any new danger. Two or three years patience will at laſt crown us with happineſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Such a tedious delay is worſe than inconſtancy. Let us fly, my charmer. Let us date our happineſs from this very moment. Periſh fortune! Love and content will encreaſe what we poſſeſs beyond a monarch's revenue. Let me prevail?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: No, Mr. Haſtings; no. Prudence once more comes to my relief, and I will obey its dictates. In the moment of paſſion, fortune may be deſpiſed, but it ever produces a laſting repentance. I'm reſolved to apply to Mr. Hardcaſtle's compaſion and juſtice for redreſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But though he had the will, he has not the power to relieve you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But he has influence, and upon that I am reſolved to rely.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I have no hopes. But ſince you perſiſt, I muſt reluctantly obey you.

sp.speaker: SCENE changes.
sp.p: Enter Sir CHARLES and Miſs HARDCASTLE.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p:
What a ſituation am I in! If what you ſay appears, I ſhall then find a guilty ſon. If what he
ſays be true, I ſhall then loſe one, that, of all others, I moſt wiſh'd for a daughter.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I am proud of your approbation, and to ſhew I merit it, if you place yourſelves as I directed, you ſhall hear his explicit declaration. But he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: I'll to your father, and keep him to the appointment.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Though prepar'd for ſetting out, I come once more to take leave, nor did I, till this moment, know the pain I feel in the ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (In her own natural manner) I believe theſe ſufferings cannot be very great, Sir, which you can ſo eaſily remove. A day or two longer, perhaps, might leſſen your uneaſineſs, by ſhewing the little value of what you now think proper to regret.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
(Aſide) This girl every moment improves upon me. (To her) It muſt not be, madam. I have already trifled too long with my heart. My very pride begins to ſubmit to my paſſion. The diſparity of education and fortune, the anger of a parent, and the contempt of my equals, begin to loſe their
weight; and nothing can reſtore me to myſelf, but this painſul effort of reſolution.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then go, Sir. I'll urge nothing more to detain you. Though my family be as good as hers you came down to viſit, and my education, I hope, not inferior, what are theſe advantages without equal affluence? I muſt remain contented with the ſlight approbation of imputed merit; I muſt have only the mockery of your addreſſes, while all your ſerious aims are fixed on fortune.

div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE and Sir CHARLES from behind.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: Here, behind this ſcreen.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, aye, make no noiſe. I'll engage my Kate covers him with confuſion at laſt.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
By Heavens, madam, fortune was ever my ſmalleſt conſideration. Your beauty at firſt caught my eye; for who could ſee that without emotion. But every moment that I converſe with you, ſteals in ſome new grace, heightens the picture, and gives it ſtronger expreſſion. What at firſt ſeem'd ruſtic plainneſs, now appears reſin'd ſimplicity. What
ſeem'd forward aſſurance, now ſtrikes me as the reſult of courageous innocence, and conſcious virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: What can it mean? He amazes me!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I told you how it would be. Huſh!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I am now determined to ſtay, madam, and I have too good an opinion of my father's diſcernment, when he ſees you, to doubt his approbation.
Miſs HARDCASTLE.

No, Mr. Marlow, I will not, cannot detain you. Do you think I could ſuffer a connexion, in which there is the ſmalleſt room for repentance? Do you think I would take the mean advantage of a tranſient paſſion, to load you with confuſion? Do you think I could ever reliſh that happineſs, which was acquired by leſſening yours?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: By all that's good, I can have no happineſs but what's in your power to grant me. Nor ſhall I ever feel repentance, but in not having ſeen your merits before. I will ſtay, even contrary to your wiſhes; and though you ſhould perſiſt to ſhun me, I will make my reſpectful aſſiduities atone for the levity of my paſt conduſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Sir, I muſt entreat you'll deſiſt. As our acquaintance began, ſo let it end, in indifference. I
might have given an hour or two to levity; but ſeriouſly, Mr. Marlow, do you think I could ever ſubmit to a connexion, where I muſt appear mercenary, and you imprudent? do you think I could ever catch at the confident addreſſes of a ſecure admirer?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: (Kneeling) Does this look like ſecurity? Does this look like confidence? No, madam, every moment that ſhews me your merit, only ſerves to encreaſe my diffidence and confuſion. Here let me continue—

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: I can hold it no longer. Charles, Charles, how haſt thou deceived me! Is this your indifference, your unintereſting converſation!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Your cold contempt; your formal interview. What have you to ſay now?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: That I'm all amazement! What can it mean!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: It means that you can ſay and unſay things at pleaſure. That you can addreſs a lady in private, and deny it in public; that you have one ſtory for us, and another for my daughter!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Daughter!—this lady your daughter!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, my only daughter. My Kate, whoſe elſe ſhould ſhe be?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Oh, the devil!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, that very identical tall ſquinting lady you were pleaſed to take me for, (curteſying) ſhe that you addreſſed as the mild, modeſt, ſentimental man of gravity, and the bold forward agreeable Rattle of the ladies club; ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Zounds, there's no bearing this; it's worſe than death.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: In which of your characters, Sir, will you give us leave to addreſs you. As the faultering gentleman, with looks on the ground, that ſpeaks juſt to be heard, and hates hypocriſy; or the loud confident creature, that keeps it up with Mrs. Mantrap, and old Miſs Biddy Buckſkin, till three in the morning: ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: O, curſe on my noiſy head. I never attempted to be impudent yet, that I was not taken down. I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: By the hand of my body, but you ſhall not. I ſee it was all a miſtake, and I am rejoiced to find it. You ſhall not, Sir, I tell you. I know ſhe'll forgive you. Won't you forgive him, Kate. We'll all forgive you. Take courage, man.
They retire, ſhe tormenting him to the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: So, ſo, they're gone off. Let them go, I care not.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Who gone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My dutiful niece and her gentleman, Mr. Haſtings, from town. He who came down with our modeſt viſitor here.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: Who, my honeſt George Haſtings! As worthy a fellow as lives, and the girl could not have made a more prudent choice.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then, by the hand of my body, I'm proud of the connexion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, if he has taken away the lady, he has not taken her fortune, that remains in this family to conſole us for her loſs.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sure, Dorothy, you would not be ſo mercenary?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Aye, but he's not of age, and ſhe has not thought proper to wait for his refuſal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Aſide) What, returned ſo ſoon! I begin not to like it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (To Hardcaſtle) For my late attempt to fly off with your niece, let my preſent confuſion be my puniſhment. We are now come back, to appeal from your juſtice to your humanity. By her father's conſent, I firſt paid her my addreſſes, and our paſſions were firſt founded in duty.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Since his death, I have been obliged to ſtoop to diſſimulation to avoid oppreſſion. In an hour of levity, I was ready even to give up my fortune to ſecure my choice. But I'm now recover'd from the deluſion, and hope from your tenderneſs what is denied me from a nearer connexion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw, this is all but the whining end of a modern novel.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Be it what it will, I'm glad they're come back to reclaim their due. Come hither, Tony boy. Do you refuſe this lady's hand whom I now offer you?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What ſignifies my refuſing. You know I can't refuſe her till I'm of age, father.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: While I thought concealing your age, boy, was likely to conduce to your improvement, I concurred with your mother's deſire to keep it ſecret. But ſince I find ſhe turns it to a wrong uſe, I muſt now declare, you have been of age theſe three months.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Of age I Am I of age, father?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Above three months.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Then you'll ſee the firſt uſe I'll make of my liberty. (Taking Miſs Neville's band) Witneſs all men by theſe preſents, that I, Anthony Lumpkin, eſquire, of BLANK place, refuſe you, Conſtantia Neville, ſpinſter, of no place at all, for my true and lawful wife. So Conſtance Neville may marry whom ſhe pleaſes, and Tony Lumpkin is his own man again.

sp.speaker: Sir CHARLES.
sp.p: O brave 'ſquire!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My worthy friend!
Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
My undutiful offspring!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Joy, my dear George, I give you joy ſincerely And could I prevail upon my little tyrant here to be leſs arbitrary, I should be the happieſt man alive, if you would return me the ſavour.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: (To Miſs Hardcaſtle) Come, madam, you are now driven to the very laſt ſcene of all your contrivances. I know you like him, I'm ſure he loves yon, and you muſt and ſhall have him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: (Joining their hands) And I ſay ſo too. And, Mr. Marlow, if ſhe makes as good a wife as ſhe has a daughter, I don't believe you'll ever repent your bargain. So now to ſupper. To-morrow we ſhall gather all the poor of the pariſh about us, and the miſtakes of the night ſhall be crowned with a merry morning; ſo, boy, take her; and as you have been miſtaken in the miſtreſs, my wiſh is, that you may never be miſtaken in the wife.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: WELL, having ſtoop'd to conquer with ſucceſs,
And gain'd a huſband without aid from dreſs,
Still as a bar-maid, I could wiſh it too,
As I have conquer'd him to conquer you:
And let me ſay, for all your reſolution,
That pretty bar-maids have done execution.
Our life is all a play, compos'd to pleaſe,
" We have our exits and our entrances."
The firſt act ſhews the ſimple country maid,
Harmleſs and young, of every thing afraid;
Bluſhes when hir'd, and with unmeaning action,
" I hopes as how to give you ſatisfaction."
Her ſecond act diſplays a livelier ſcene.—
Th' unbluſhing bar-maid of a country inn,
Who whiſks about the houſe, at market caters,
Talks loud, coquets the gueſts, and ſcolds the waiters.
Next the ſcene ſhifts to town, and there ſhe ſoars,
The chop-houſe toaſt of ogling connoiſieurs.
On 'ſquires and cits ſhe there diſplays her arts,
And on the gridiron broils her lover's hearts—
And as ſhe ſmiles, her triumphs to compleat,
Even common councilmen forget to eat.
The fourth act ſhews her wedded to the 'ſquire,
And madam now begins to hold it higher;
Pretends to taſte, at operas cries caro,
And quits her Nancy Dawſon, for Che Faro.
Doats upon dancing, and in all her pride,
Swims round the room, the Heinell of Cheapſide:
Ogles and leers with artificial ſkill,
Till having loſt in age the power to kill,
She ſits all night at cards, and ogles at ſpadille.
Such, through our lives, the eventful hiſtory—
The fifth and laſt act ſtill remains for me.
The bar-maid now for your protection prays,
Turns female Barriſter, and pleads for Bays.

head.hi: TO BE SPOKEN IN THE CHARACTER OF TONY LUMPKIN.This came too late to be ſpoken.

lg.l: WELL—now all's ended—and my comrades gone,
Pray what becomes of mother's nonly ſon?
A hopeful blade!—in town I'll fix my ſtation,
And try to make a bluſter in the nation.
As for my couſin Neville, I renounce her,
Off—in a crack—I'll carry big Bett Bouncer.
Why ſhould not I in the great world appear?
I ſoon ſhall have a thouſand pounds a year?
No matter what a man may here inherit,
In London—'gad, they have ſome regard to ſpirit.
I ſee the horſes prancing up the ſtreets,
And big Bett Bouncer, bobs to all ſhe meets;
Then hoikes to jiggs and paſtimes ev'ry night—
Not to the plays—they ſay it a'n't polite;
To Sadler's-Wells perhaps, or operas go,
And once by chance, to the roratorio.
Thus here and there, for ever up and down,
We'll ſet the faſhions too, to half the town;
And then at auctions—money ne'er regard,
Buy pictures like the great, ten pounds a yard;
Zounds, we ſhall make theſe London gentry ſay,
We know what's damn'd genteel as well as they.
